conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a region where the light is not directly visible.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface on which the shadow is cast.
The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are elongated due to the angle of the light source.
When the light source moves backward, it changes the angle at which the light rays hit the objects.
The angle of incidence of the light rays on the objects decreases, meaning the light rays are more parallel to the ground.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will shift forward.
The shadows will shift forward because the light rays are now coming from a direction that is more behind the objects, causing the shadows to project further in front of the objects.
The size of the shadows will decrease.
The shadows become more compact and less elongated because the light rays are more parallel to the ground, reducing the spread of the shadow.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift forward and become smaller.
